title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act may be cited as the "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" and includes a drug screening and testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" requires states to implement a drug screening and testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The program includes screening all applicants for illegal drug use and testing those at high risk of substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to conduct drug screening and testing for applicants and recipients of assistance. The program involves screening all applicants for illegal drug use and testing individuals at high risk of substance abuse. States may continue testing individuals at random intervals after the initial screening. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to screen and test individuals for illegal drug use before providing assistance. Screening is done through an effective survey method, and testing is required for those at high risk of substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to screen and test individuals for illegal drug use before providing assistance. Screening is conducted through a survey method, and testing is required for those identified as high risk for substance abuse. The Act also prohibits waivers for these provisions. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates states to screen and test individuals for illegal drug use before providing assistance. The Secretary cannot waive these provisions. An illegal drug is defined as a controlled substance. If an individual is denied assistance, the State must continue to provide assistance to other family members. The amendments made by this section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter that begins on or after the date that is 1 year after the enactment of the Act, unless State legislation is required for compliance. The Act requires compliance with new requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the State legislature's regular session. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
